abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Sector Reorientation Project
            in Lesotho was implemented. Although the Project was able to
            achieve parts of its physical objectives, the overall
            outcome is unsatisfactory, due to development objectives on
            the institutional side not being met and lack of
            sustainability. On the whole, the Bank's performance is
            deemed satisfactory. The Project was prepared in close
            coordination with the Government of Lesotho (GOL), and its
            focus adequately put on institutional reforms. However, the
            pace at which continuing policy reforms could be implemented
            and capacity building strengthened under this very Project
            did not materialize as expected due to institutional changes
            and to the complex political environment at that time. The
            key lessons drawn for project implementation and defining
            policy reforms in the urban sector are that: The involvement
            and commitment of all stakeholders, including beneficiaries,
            from the preparation stage is a necessary ingredient to
            success. Up front policy action plans to be agreed in
            collaboration with all stakeholders, and restructuring are
            required to bring about changes.
